div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez every Thursday at 5 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Throughout Saturday the wind blew very strong from the S.W., with a very rough sea and cloudy. At sunset the weather became squally, strong gusts of wind blowing violently at times with a velocity of 68 kilometers per hour. There were frequent heavy showers during the squalls throughout the night.
Yesterday a continuous strong S. Westerly wind blew, with a rough sea. Clear weather prevailed throughout the day, and also during the night. Barometer steadily rising.
For the 24 hours ending Yesterday

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.p: RAILWAY RETURN TICKETS We notice that several of our contemporaries assert that return tickets are to be re-introduced on the Egyptian State Railways. Their Absence is one of the many things that may have struck the members of the recent Railway Commission, and may have been remarked upon by them, any knowledge of which (may be held to be sufficient ground for stating that the want will be immediately supplied. These tickets were in force in former times and abolished because of the openings they afforded for their fraudulent use. Things are more orderly now, but on the other hand, the passenger traffic is heavier to deal with, and generally speaking, we do not see on the Egyptian State Railways the existence of those precautions necessary to control crowds of passengers. Until provision for these is made we shall be surprised if return tickets are introduced-it would only be courting failure.

THE SUEZ CANAL The new Suez Canal proposals may be only a threat, and the scheme may be impracticable, but it has certainly creaated a stir among the governing body of the Canal. A considerable amount of correspondence bearing on the question has passed between Egypt and Paris, with the result that four members of the head administration, two French, one British, and one Dutch, have arrived at Port-Said, and are busily engaged, amongst other things, in inspecting the new harbour works, in the company M. Tillier, director-general from Cairo, and M. Coulant, director at Port-Said. It is much to be regretted that the Canal Company cannot see their way to give some public indication of the nature of their scheme. From an outsidder's point of view, the progress of the works appears to be so slow, and the plant and personnel are so trivial for such a gigantic piece of work, that no real por extension seems likely to be accomplished for many years. One would think that the present rate of development of the country, and the congested state of the port of Alexandria, would warrant the company's tackling this large scheme in a more serious and energetic manner.

div.head: FORT ARTHUR FORMAL ENTRY OF JAPS. SURRENDER INEXPLICABLE.

div.p: The Japanese have formally entered Port Arthur. Detachments of all arms are marching to the sound of the bugle in the old and new towns. (Reuter)
The surrender of Port Arthur is inexplicable because there were no signs of privation. The prisoners number upwards of 24,000, excluding the sick and wounded. (Reuter.)

div.head: TSAR AND PORT ARTHUR CONFIDENCE IN THE FUTURE

div.p: The Tsar in an order of the day to the Army and Navy announcing the fall of Port Arthur, eulogizes the glorious garrison whose heroism Russia has witnessed with pride. The order adds: "Peace he to the ashes of the dead, and glory to the living. Our enemy is bold and strong. The struggle at such a distance is indescribably hard, but Russia is powerful, and has undergone harder trials in the past from which she always emerged more powerful. While lamenting our losses, we must not become distracted. With all Russia, I trust that the hour of victory will soon dawn and I pray God to bless our troops and fleets so that they may be able to uphold the glory of Russia." (Reuter.)
An order of the day by the Tsar praises the heroic defence of Port Arthur and foresees the early triumph of Russia. (Havas.)
General Stoessel arrived here in the afternoon. The Governor, with a guard of honor, welcomed him.

div.head:
RÚSSIANS AT NIU-CHWANG.
OLD TOWN OCCUPIED.

div.p: The Russians left 62 killed and 6 wounded at Niuchwang. Their total casualties there and at Niuchatun are estimated at 300, and the Japanese at 16. The Japanese stores and magazines were not damaged. (Reuter.)
Reuter's correspondent with General Kuroki says that the Russian raiders traversed the neutral territory west of the Liao, and occupied the old town of Niuchwang. (Reuter.).
The Press and the public are sharply criticising France for permitting a prolonged stay of the Baltic Fleet at Madagascar. (Reuter.)
The Japanese have captured the British collier "Lethingtun" en route for Vladivostok.
(Reuter.)
The "Novoya Vremia" publishes a telegram from Java stating that the Japanese have established a naval base at Labuan, aud that the cable has ceased working for the purpose of concealing the fact.
(Reuter.)
The Admiralty is preparing a fleet of submarines.
(Havas.)

The report on the Budget presented by the Russian Minister of Finance shows an estimated decrease of 65} million roubles compared with 1904. The lessened expenditure will be mainly in the Finance and Communications departments. Ten million roubles is assigned for the doubling of the Siberian Railway, and another 18 million roubles to cover extra expenditure on the Trans-Baikal line. Everything in the budget is calculated to strengthen confidence in the finances of Russia, whose monetary system and national economy remain unshakeu atter 11 months' war. (Reuter.)

The Russian Note to the Powers, with reference to China's neglect of her neutrality, is regarded here as absurd, seeing that the Russian cavalry raid was made from Chinese territory. It is felt that China's weakness and the constant failure to enforce her neutrality must relieve Japan of her obligation to observe the restrictions which Russia herself ignores. Japan must protest against the repetition of raids whose success would be due to the violation of neutral territory.
(Reuter.)
M. Mascuraud has been elected senator.
(Havas.)
Wales 25 points. England nil. (Reuter.)
Earl Cairns is dead.
(Reuter.)

Although the Earldom was only created in 1878 there is now a fourth Earl owing to the death of the second son of the great Chancellor. The late Earl was born in 1863 and succeeded his brother in 1890. He was educated at Wellington College and was a partner in the Elswick Ordnance Company. Being unmarried, he is succeeded by his brother, the Hon. Wilfrid Dallas Cairns, a major in the 5th Battalion of the Rifle Brigade. He was born in 1865 and married in 1894 the daughter of the late Mr. Cobbold.

div.head: THE COMBES CABINET.
div.p: TOTTERING TO ITS FALL
"SCENE" IN FRENCH CHAMBER

Paris, January 14. CHAMBER OF DEPUTIES.-M. Combes stated that the Government had suppressed delation, and recalled the reforms which had been accomplished. He added that he had presented other practical reforms, which were realisable. The Chamber would say whether it wished tu continue to go ahead or accept reaction.
After M. Ribot had spoken, M.M. Berteaux and Jaurès adjured the Republicans to become reconciled in the interests of the country. | The Chamber passed by 289 votes against
279, the Bienvenu Martin order of the day, | which was accepted by M. Combes, approving
the declarations and programme of the Goverument. |. The impression prevailing in the lobbies is that the Government will resign. (Havus.)

PARIS, January 15. During the debate in the Chamber, M. Combes vigorously repudiated the charge of sowing dissension amongst the Republicans by his anti-Clerical persecution. He adhered to bis programme despite the coalition of imI patient ambitions confronting him.

The debate was disorderly. The Royalist M. Baudry d'Asson advanced towards M. Combes | brandishing a huge copper saucepan signifying in French slang "in ormer." He was ejected. The Chamber passed a vote of confidence in the Ministry by 289 votes against 279.
It is expected that the Cabinet will resign owing to the smallness of the majority. (R.)
PARIS, January 15. The Ministerial crisis is virtually open. Its solution has been adjourned owing to the death of M. Loubet's píother.

div.head: INSPECTION.-
div.p: Major-General Slade inspected the 56th Battery R.F.A. and 4th Mountain Battery R.G.A. at Abbassieh this morning.

div.head: Cairo FETES.-
div.p: The concert organised by the Comité des Fêtes, which is to be tollowed by a small dance, at the Savoy Hotel, will take | place on Friday, 27th inst.

div.head: THE "MAHROUSSA."—
div.p: The Khedive's yacht "Mabroussa," which sailed from Malta on Saturday week for Glasgow, had to return to port, being weatherbound. She left the next day.

div.head: COAL IMPORTS. -
div.p: The imports of coal from the 1st to the 12th inst. amounted to 9,544 | tons, as against 9,326 for the same period last year. Newcastle sent 2,749 tons, the Welsh district 6,598 tons, other places 197 tons.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.-
div.p: On the 11th and 12th inst. 41 vessels passed through the Canal. Of these, 23 were British, 5 German, 1 Austrian, 1 Egyptian, 1 Spanish, 1 Dutch, 7. Russian, 2 French. The receipts for the two days were frs. 934,531.78. The total receipts from 1st to 12th inst. amounted to frs. 4,472,608.45.

div.head: | CHILDREN'S SAVINGS. -
div.p: As will have been seen from a notice from the postal authorities we published on Saturday, the issue of the children's 'saving cards" has commenced. So that now it is in the power of any of our young friends to take the first step towards accumulating funds for future needs, and to place their small savings in safe keeping.

div.head: RIFLE MEETING.—
div.p: The following is the list of members of the committee entrusted with the arrangements for the forthcoming Rifle Meeting at Cairo :-Captain A. N. Tucker, R.E., 2nd-Lieut. E. R. Lloyd, 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, Lieut. G. P. Hunt, 2nd Royal Berks. Regiment, 2nd-Lieut. R. 8. H. Walpole, Det., 2nd Rifle Brigade, and Lieut. E. P. Blencowe, A.S.C.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL CLUB.-
div.p: The balance sheet of the Khedivial Club, Alexandria, will be submitted to the general meeting of permanent members on Monday, 23rd inst. The club record for the past year is a splendid one, as the balancesheet shows & net profit of L.E. 3,864. The receipts show a considerable increase all round compared with the figures for 1903. For example, the entrance fees and subscriptions have increased from L.E. 2,900 to L.E. 3,692, the card playing fees, from L.E. 1,180 to L.E. 4,969, the cigars and cigarettes, from L.E. 77 to L.E. 110, and the total receipts from L.E. 4,988 to L.E. 9,425, an augmentation of nearly 50 per cent.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL,
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
Ten minutes from Alexandria. Tirst-Olass in every respect. Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable Englisb| buarter. Visitors from Cairo Alight st Sidi Gaber Station. 14441-84-6-90B
(1, AQUILINA, Proprietar,
GRAND HOTEL BONNARDI
ALEXANDRIA. 88. PER DAY, WINE INCLUDED.
QUARR.10.7.OK

div.head: ARRIVAL OF SWEDISH PRINCE
div.p: VESSEL AGROUND IN THE PORT.

Prince Gustavus Adolphus is a passenger by the Norddeutscher Lloyd S.S. "Hohenzollern," which arrived at Alexandria this forenoon on her maiden trip from Marseilles. The vessel entered the Boghaz Pass at 11.50 o'clock, and was due alongside the quay shortly after midday. But owing to her draught she found difficulty in getting through the pass and grounded. As we go to press we learn that she is again afloat and coming into the
harbour. -1 Prince Oscar Frederick William Olaf Gus

tavus Adolphus, Duke of Scania, is the son of the Crown Prince of Norway and Sweden, Prince Oscar Gustavus Adolphus, Duke of Vermeland and of his wife, who was Princess Victoria of Baden. The Prince was born at Stockholm in 1882. His father and mother paid a visit to Egypt in 1892 and the following year when they were here for about four months, on each occasion spending most of their time on the river in a dahabieh. 1/ The Prince'e visit will probably last for two months and after seeing the sights of Cairo he is going up the river. A suite of rooms has | been reserved for him at Shepheard's Hotel.
The Swedish and Norwegian vessels in the | harbour were dresssed to-day in honor of the Prince's arrival.
The Wilson liner "Toro" hoisted the Swedish flag on the arrival of the Prince.

The "Hohenzollern," has a length of 449 feet; a breadth of 51 feet, and a depth of 35 feet. l'he ship has two masts and two massive fun nels. She is built of steel and is divided into 12 water-tight compartments by stout bulkheads. Her engines indicate 7,500 horse power. Her average sea speed is between 16 and 17 knots an hour. The open gangways along the sides of the midships deckhouse on the upper deck give the ship a very graceful appearance. The promenade deck, which is free of all obstructions and lit at night by electric lamps from overhead, is throughout its entire | length of 250 feet covered by a permanent awn

ing deck, upon which the numerous life-boats are carried ready for immediate use. At the | after end of the promenade deck is the firstclass smoke room, spacious, airy, and elegantly appointed. Forward on the same deck is the entrance to the upper vestibule, out of which open the ladies' room and the music room. The saloon is on the upper deck. The state rooms for first class passengers are on the main deck. At the foot of the staircase is a large vestibule from the after part of which run the two corridors leading to the state rooms, bath rooms, etc. The state rooms contain two berths, & wardrobe, two wash stands, a chest of drawers, | a writing table, and a sofa couch.

The steamer has accommodation for 168 first and 79 second class passengers. The second class accommodation is in the after part of the ship, and is as spacious and comfortable as the first class, if not so luxuriously appointed. The lower deck and the fore part of the ship are reserved for steerage passengers, of whom 950 can be carried. Every possible precaution had been taken to ensure the ship's safety.

div.head: SAVOY SMALL DANCE.
div.p: Last Saturday's dance at the Savoy was a very brilliant social function. The big dancinghall, as well as the enlarged restaurant, proved too small to hold the whole of the members of society who have chosen the Savoy as their favorite rendez-vous. An extra dining room bad to be added as over 150 extra dinIners were served in the restaurant. Mr. and Mrs. Ing had a party of 10, including Mr. and Mrs. A. Joseph, Miss Joseph, and Mr. Aspinall. Lady Clarke entertained a party which included Col, and Mrs. Peake, Mr. Higgins, Mr. Tod, Mr. and Mrs. Scott-Dalgleish, Mrs. Jay and Mr. H.H. Kelly. Dr. Armstrong had a party of 4. We also notic ed M. and Mme Pierre Lebaudy with Comte de Marsey and Mr. Luzarche d'Azay, M. đe Bilinsky and a large party, including H. E. and Mrs. Crookshank Pasha, Dr. and Mrs. Warnock, Dr. and Mrs. Madden, Mr. Henriques, Miss Malcolm Morris, Mrs. Wallich. At another table were Mr. and Mrs. Bell with a large party, including Col. and Mrs. J. K. Watson, Capt. MacBarnett, Mr. and Mrs. Crawley, Capt. Lemprière, Capt. Lewin, and Miss Stevenson. Mr. Charles Royle's party included Mr. George Royle and Miss Royle, Birch Bey had 7 guests including Mr. Webb and Major and Mrs. Spong. Dr. Armstrong entertained 4 guests ; Mrs. and and the Misses Simon entertained a party of 8 ; Mr. Morgan, of the U.S. Consulate, a party of 5, etc.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner "Tabor" sailed hence on Saturday afternoon for Liverpool, viâ Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo, including 3,949 bales cotton.
The Cunard S.S. "Veris" is due here to-day from Patras.
The Moss liner "Seti" arrived here this morning from Liverpool, via Gibraltar, Algiers, and Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Messageries Maritime S.S. "Sydney," | from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday and is due here to-morrow morning.
The Khedivial 8.8. "Assouan" will leave Alexandria on Wednesday for Port Said and Suez.

div.head: EGYPTIAN DELTA LAND AND INVESTMENT.
div.p: EXTRAORDINARY MEETING.

*London, January 10. An extraordinary meeting of this company I was held this afternoon at Winchester House. Sir A. Colvin, who presided, said that when the company was formed it was | fully realised by the board that before a

considerable time had elapsed they would have occasion to ask the shareholders to sanction an increase of capital ; but it was not thought it would have been necessary to call a meeting for that purpose in so
short a time after the formation of the company. | The directors had already purchased 700 feddans

of land most advantageously situated for buildJing purposes, and they were negotiating for other parcels which, if acquired, would more than absorb all the existing capital. In addition to this, there were other pieces of land suitable to their aims which the board were inquiring into with a view to early purchase if they could obtain it at a reasonable price. It would be impossible, without serioas detriment to the company's interests, I to inform the shareholders more definitely as to

the price they were giving or offering for lands already purchased or under negotiation,or of the localities in which these lands were situated. The directors must ask for the proprietors'confidence and support. The board were of opinion
that so far the purchases were good and sound | investiments, and when developed and realised

appeared likely to yield good returns. He moved a resolution increasing the capital from £100,000 to £250,000 by the creation of 150,000 further shares of £1 each.—Lieut.Col. E. L. Marryat seconded the motion, and it was carried.

div.head: LAND BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: The following are the objects of the new Land Bank, as stated in the statutes of the company :
1. De prêter sur hypothèques aux propriétaires d'immeubles en Egypte des sommes remboursables soit à long terme par annuités,
soit à court terme, avec ou sans amortissement; | 2. De faire l'acquisition de créances bypo
thécaires, d'ouvrir des crédits en comptes courants sur hypothèque; .

3. De faire des avances aux cultivateurs propriétaires ruraux sans affectation hypothécaire, pour les besoins de leurs cultures annuelles, mais dans les limites des revenus de leurs terres et d'escompter leurs billets à ordre dans les mêmes limites et par aval;
4. De recevoir des capitaux en dépôt avec ou sans intérêt. | Mr. Joseph T. Aghion has been appointed managing director of the Bank

div.head: FREE STATE LANDS.
div.p: The Free State Lands Department is selling & quantity of land in the neighbourhood of Alexandria. This morning there was a sale by auction at the Gouvernorat of thirteen lots of land, about 1,000 square pics, in the Moharrem Bey quarter. The last was situated behind the Jewish Hospital. The highest price realised was at the rate of PT. 70 the square metre.

div.head: CAIRO HOTELS.
div.p: We are asked to contradict the report of a fusion between the Nungovich Hotels and the hotels of Mr. Baehler at Cairo.

div.head: SLAVE TRADERS ARRESTED..
div.p: A patrol under the orders of the Department for the Suppression of the Slave Trade, while passing Eteai from Geraw, in the desert S.E. of Assouan, received information that two Bishareen Arabs had bought a Sudani girl, called Howa, and were taking her to the coast to sell to Hedjazi Arabs.

The patrol followed their track and succeeded in catching the two slave dealers before the sale of the girl had been accomplished. They were taken back to Eteai, where the officer in command made a preliminary enquiry into the affair, in consequence of which the prisoners and the girl were sent to Cairo viâ Assouan. They arrived on Saturday and will be tried by a special court at the War Office
The girl, who was brought to Cairo as a witness, has of course been liberated.

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE.
div.p: This theatre was literally packed from floor to ceiling yesterday afternoon, when the comic opera "Capitan Teresa," which has been such & tremendous success, kept the audience in continuous merriment, and the several artistes were cheered to the echo. In the evening another large audience were treated to an excellent performance of Varney's "Il Pompiere di Servizio," in which each and every artiste scored a distinct success. Signor Gravina, it need hardly be said, kept the audience in roers of laughter. Surely no "touch of the blues" could withstand Signor Cravina's treatment. Signorina E. Casalis made & very charming Fanny Bodard, and was heartily applauded. The opera was beautifully staged, the costumes being particularly handsome. To-night "Il Duchino" will be produced, and we strongly advise all our readers not to miss the opportunity of enjoying & thoroughly first-class performance.

div.head: EDEN PALACE HOTEL
div.p: CAIRO Open all the year round, ELECTRIO LICN1, Lift, - NODERATE CHAROES

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: Owing to the sanitary situation of Egypt, the Turkish Government has decided to impose five days' quarantine on arrivals in Ottoman ports from Egypt. As regards the Egyptian pilgrims, this preliminary five days' quarantine will be purged at Tor and will entail a quarantine fee of P.T. 50, which will be collected at Suez before the pilgrims embark.
Persons wishing to go on the pilgrimage should be at Suez as soon as possible. Departures for Tor will take place on January 20, 21, 23, 24, 25, 26, 28, 29, and 31.

div.head: NEW NILE FERRY SERVICE.
div.p: On Saturday last, at 2.30 p.m., the ferry service between Rod-el-Farag and Ghizeh was opened by the Compagnie des Bateaux Omnibus. The new boat, which has been built at Messrs. Cook's engineering works at Boulac, took about 100 passengers on the preliminary trip to Rod-el-Farag from Ghizeh.

Among those invited we noticed the Minister of War, the Governor of Cairo, Mr. Courtenay Clifton, Messrs. A. and L. Suares, Mr. F. Cattani, Mr. Vernon Jarvis, and many representatives of the Press. Champagne was served out liberally in honor of the occasion, and all those invited were loud in their praise of the hospitality extended to them by the company, whose principal representative on the occasion was M. Adolphe Cattaui.

div.head: MINISTRY OF FINANCE.
div.p: Mr. Vincent Corbett is expected back from Khartoum at the end of this week. Mr. Anthony, director of the Government Land Department at the above Ministry, who had accompanied the Financial Adviser and Mr. Bowden-Smith, his private secretary, as far as Assouan, returned to Cairo yesterday. | Mr. L. G. Roussin has entered upon his new duties at this Ministry, provisionally as assistant to Mesciaca Bey, director of the Treasury.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie) Le marché des valeurs acouse aujourd'hui une hausse géuérale. L'entrain règne sur toute la ligne. Un chiffre d'affaires considérable a été fait en Banque Nationale, en Filature, en Daïra et en Nungovich..
La Banque Nationale atteint 24 7/16, l'Agricole 10 1/8, la Delta Land 3 15/16, la Daïra 22 7/16, la Spinning 1 1/32.
La Crown Brewery remonte à 220, la Brasserie des Pyramides à 127, les Cotton Mills à 7/6, la Salt and Soda à 43, les Nungovich à 10 3/16 et l'Anglo American Nile à 5 1/4.
On demande les Eaux d'Alexandrie à 15 7/8, la Delta Light à 14 9/16, les Privilégiées Tramways à 144 et la Ramleh Railway à 8 1/4.
La tenue est exoqusivement forme.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: | The Khedive will grant an audience on | Thursday next at Abdeen Palace to M. Paul Plan, the leading actor in the French comedy company at the Zizinis Theatre, who will present his Highness with a copy of his poems.
e
O
A ball is to be given at the British Agency on Wednesday next.
The Earl and Countess of Cromer have postponed their up-river trip.
Prince Arfa-ud-Dovleh Mirza Khan Danish, Persian Ambassador to the Sublime Ottoman
Porte, who has been staying at the Carlton -Hotel, Bulkeley, since Monday last, is leaving
| by the midday express to-morrow for Cairo.

| The latest arrivals at Shepheard's Hotel include :-Mr. Thomas Gibson Bowles, M.P., Baron von der Planitz and party, Baron von Walzdorf, Baron von Schilling, Mr. J. W. wig" and the White Star liner " Canopic," which are due at Alexandria on the 24th and 25th inst., will bring such a crowd to Shepheard's Hotel and Ghezireh Palace that the management have refused further bookings until February

Mrs. Keatinge is giving an "at home" at Rodah Island on the 31st inst., on the occasion of the first race of the new River Club
| Col. and Mrs. Jago have left the Savoy Hotel for Upper Egypt.
Major and Mrs. E. Feetham have returned from Cairo and are living at the field officers' quarters, Mustapha Pasha barracks.
| Lieut. C. H. T. Lucas, 2nd Battalion R. Berks. Regiment, has been granted leave of absence from to-day to March 16.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: |_ COURS D'ASSISES La loi instituant les Cours d'Assises vient de paraitre à "l'Officiel". En voici les principales dispositions :| Compétence, organisation.- Sauf application de l'art. 55, les faits qualifiés crimes par la

loi seront jugés par les cours d'Assises, à Ji exception de ceux dont la connaissance est déférée à des juridictions spéciales. Les assises se tiendront partout où fonctionne un tribunal de lère instance. Elles seront composées de 3 conseillers de la Cour d'Appel, délégués par le ministre de la Justice, sur la proposition du président de la Cour d'Appel. Elles siègeront chaque mois et de jour en jour jusqu'à ce que le rôle de la session soit vidé.

Renvoi devant la Cour d'Assises.-- Toute | affaire criminelle instruite par le parquet sera confiée à l'examen d'un juge de renvoi ayant d'être portée devant la Cour d'Assises. Le juge de renvoi, après son examen, qui devra être terminé dans la huitaine, renverra l'affaire suivant le cas à la Cour d'Assises, s'il y a présomption de crime, au parquet, s'il s'agit de délit ou de contravention, à la Cour d'Assises, s'il y a connexité de crime et de délit; il pourra également rendre une ordonnance de non-lieu ou réclamer une instruction complémentaire. Le prooureur général pourra dang les 18 jours se pourvoir contre une ordonnance du juge de renvoi par devant la Cour d'Appel. La Cour statuera sur le pourvoi.
De la détention préventive.—Aussitôt que le juge de renvoi est saisi d'une affaire, il sera le seul compétent pour statuer sur la détention préventive.

Des témoins.- Le juge de renvoi pourvoirs dans les formes à la citation des témoins à charge et à décharge, à moins qu'il ne juge que cette citation a été demandée dans un seul but dilatoire ou vexatoire.
De la fixation de la session. — Le juge de renvoi fixera la date de la session. Si l'acound
